details.title: Present continuous for ongoing actions

details.title: Present simple
details.content: Drive(s)/ work(s)/ do(es) - present simple'-yň ýasalma formasy.
details.example: I/we/you/they drive/work/do and he/she/it drives/works/does

details.title: Present Simple Usage
details.content: Present simple iş-herekt barada umumy gürrüň edilende ulanylýar, ondan häzirki pursatda bolup hereket barada nazarda tutmak üçin ulanylmaýar. Onda ýygy-ýygydan gaýtalanyp durýan herekti, hem-de umuman alnanda dogry (hakykata dogry gelýän) hereketi görkezmek üçin ulanylýar.

details.title: Usage with Third Person
details.content: He/she/it bilen işlik ulanylanda 's'-i unutmaň.
details.example: I work, but He works. / They teach, but My sister teaches.

details.title: Questions and Negatives
details.content: Sorag we ýokluk sözlemleri ýasamak üçin do/does ulanylýar.
details.example: Do we/you/they work? Does he/she/it come? I/we/you/they don't work. He/she/it doesn't come.

details.title: Present Simple for Habitual Actions
details.content: Present simple iş-hereketiň hemişe gaýtalanyp durýanyny görkezmek üçin ulanylýar.
details.example: I get up at 8 o'clock every morning. - Men her gün irden sagat 8-de turýaryn.

details.title: Expressing Habits and Frequency
details.content: How often do you go to the dentist? / Ann doesn't drink tea very often.
details.example: In summer John usually plays tennis once or twice a week. - Tomusda Jon adatça hepdede bir gezek ýa-da iki gezek tennis oýnaýar.

details.title: Verbs Used in Present Simple
details.content: Apologise, promise, suggest, advise, insist, agree, refuse we şunuň ýaly iş-hereketi bildirmeýän işlikler diňe present simple'da ulanylýar.
details.example: I promise I won't be late. - gijikmezlige wada berýärin.

details.title: I am doing vs I do
details.content: Mysallary okaň we deňeşdirmeleri öwreniň:
details.example: The water is boiling. Can you turn it off? - Suw gaýnaýar. Ony öçürip bilersiňmi?

details.title: Present Continuous (I am doing)
details.content: Present Continuous - I am doing.
details.example: Listen to those people. What language are they speaking? - Hanha ol adamlary diňle. Olar haýsy dilde gürleşýärler?

details.title: Present Simple (I do)
details.content: Present Simple - I do.
details.example: Water boils at 100 degrees celsius. - Suw 100 Selsiýa gradusda gaýnaýar.

details.title: Present Continuous and Present Simple Comparison
details.content: Let's go out. It isn't raining now. - Ýörüň daşark çykalyň. Häzir ýagyş ýagmaýar.
details.example: It doesn't rain very much in summer. - Tomusda gaty köp ýagyş ýagmaýar.

details.title: Present Continuous (Action happening now)
details.content: Present Continuous is used for actions happening at the moment.
details.example: Don't disturb me. I'm busy: Why? What are you doing? - 'Maňa päsgel bermäň. Men işli.' 'Näm üçin? Name edýärsiňiz?'

details.title: Present Simple (Routine or job)
details.content: Present Simple is used for habits or regular actions.
details.example: What do you usually do at weekends? - Sen adatça hepde ahyrky günlerinde näme edýärsiň?

details.title: Present Simple (Occupation)
details.content: What do you do? (= What's your job?) - Näme iş edýärsiň? (= Hünäriňiz näme?)
details.example: I always go to bed before midnight. - Men hemişe gijäň ýaryndan öň uka gidýärin.

details.title: Present Continuous (Temporary situation)
details.content: Present Continuous is used for temporary actions or situations.
details.example: Maria is in Britain at the moment. She's learning English. - Mariya edil şuwagt Britanýada. Ol iňlis dilini öwrenýär.

details.title: Present Simple for general truths
details.content: Most people learn to swim when they are children. - Köp adamlar ýüzmäni çagalygyndan öwrenýärler.
details.example: My parents live in London. They have lived there all their lives. - Ata-enäm Londanda ýaşaýarlar. Olar ol ýer bütin ömri boýunça ýaşan.

details.title: Present Continuous vs Present Simple with 'Always'
details.content: 'Always' is typically used with Present Simple. But we also use 'I'm always doing something' to express irritation or emphasize repetition.
details.example: I always go to work by car. - Men işe hemişe maşynly gidýärin.

details.title: Present Continuous for Repeated Actions
details.content: We can use 'I'm always doing' for actions that repeat, often in a way that is annoying.
details.example: I've lost my pen again. I'm always losing things. - Men ýene ruçkamy ýitirdim. Men hemişe zatlarymy ýitirýärin.

details.title: Present Simple vs Present Continuous with 'Always'
details.content: 'You're always ...-ing' suggests that the action is repeated often, possibly to an annoying extent.
details.example: John is never satisfied. He's always complaining. - Jon hiçem göwni ýetmeýär. Ol hemişe nägile.

details.title: Present Continuous for Actions Now
details.content: 'You're always watching television' suggests that the action is done too much and might need to change.
details.example: You're always watching television. You should do something more active. - Sen hemişe telewizor görýärsiň. Sen köpräk herekt etmegiň gerek.

details.title: Present Continuous Usage
details.content: Prezent Continuous iş-hereketleri we wakalary görkezmek üçin ulanylýar (they are eating/ it is raining we ş.m)
details.example: I’m hungry. I want something to eat. - Men aç. Bir zatlar iýmek isleýän. ('l'm wanting' däl)

details.title: Verbs not used in Present Continuous
details.content: Some verbs like 'know', 'like' do not describe actions and cannot be used in Present Continuous. Example: 'I am knowing' is incorrect.
details.example: Do you understand what I mean? – Sen meniň näme diýjek bolýanyma düşünýäňmi?

details.title: Verbs that cannot be used in Present Continuous
details.content: Verbs like 'like', 'love', 'hate', 'want', 'need', 'prefer', 'know' etc. are not used in Present Continuous.
details.example: Ann doesn't seem very happy at the moment. - Anna buwagt juda şadyýan görnenak.

details.title: 'Think' in Present Continuous
details.content: 'Think' used for 'believe' is not used in Present Continuous. 'What do you think?' is correct, but 'What are you thinking?' is incorrect.
details.example: What do you think (= believe) will happen? - Siziň pikiriňizçe näme bolar?

details.title: Thinking in Present Continuous
details.content: 'Thinking' used for 'to think, to consider' is used in Present Continuous.
details.example: You look serious. What are you thinking about? - Siz gaharly görünýärsiňiz. Näme hakda pikir edýärsiňiz?

details.title: 'Have' in Present Continuous
details.content: 'Have' used for possession is not used in Present Continuous.
details.example: Do you have something to eat? – Sende iýmäge bir zatlar bamy?

details.title: 'Having' for activities in Present Continuous
details.content: 'Having' used for activities can be used in Present Continuous.
details.example: Where's Ann? 'She's having a bath' - Anna nirede? 'Ol duş kabul edýär'

details.title: Verbs like See, Hear, Smell, Taste
details.content: Verbs like 'see', 'hear', 'smell', 'taste' are usually used in Present Simple, not Present Continuous.
details.example: Do you see that man over there? – Sen ol ýerdäki adamy görýäňmi?

details.title: 'Seeing' in Present Continuous
details.content: 'See' used for meeting or encountering can be used in Present Continuous.
details.example: I'm seeing the manager tomorrow morning. – Men ertir menejer bilen görüşýärin.

details.title: 'Be' Verb in Present Continuous
details.content: The verb 'be' in Present Continuous describes someone's state or behavior at the moment. Example: 'I am being selfish' shows a temporary behavior.
details.example: I can't understand why he's being so selfish. - Men onuň şeýle özdiýenli bolşuna düşünip bilemok.

details.title: Behavior vs General State
details.content: 'Being' shows temporary behavior, while 'is' or 'are' is used for general states.
details.example: He is very selfish. - Ol örän özdiýenli.

details.title: General States vs Present Continuous
details.content: Present Continuous is not used for general states. Example: 'It is hot today' is correct, but 'It is being hot' is not.
details.example: It's hot today. - Bugün yssy.

details.title: Verbs 'Look' and 'Feel' in Present Simple vs Present Continuous
details.content: Verbs 'look' and 'feel' can be used in both Present Simple and Present Continuous for appearance or state of being.
details.example: You look well today. – Bugün oňat görünýärsiň.

details.title: Feeling and Appearance
details.content: 'How do you feel now?' vs 'How are you feeling now?' Both are used to ask about someone's current state.
details.example: How do you feel now? – Häzir özüňi nähili duýýarsyň?

details.title: Past Simple - W.A. Mozart
details.content: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was an Austrian musician and composer. He lived from 1756 to 1791. He started composing at the age of five and wrote more than 600 pieces of music. He was only 35 years old when he died.
details.example: Mozart wrote more than 600 pieces of music.

details.title: Past Simple Form of Verbs
details.content: In Past Simple, verbs usually end in –ed. Examples include 'stopped', 'studied', and 'wrote'. For irregular verbs, such as 'write' (wrote) or 'see' (saw), they change differently.
details.example: Mozart wrote more than 600 pieces of music.

details.title: Questions and Negations with Past Simple
details.content: For forming questions or negatives, use 'did/didn't' followed by the base form of the verb. Examples: Did you enjoy? / Did they go? / They didn’t invite her to the party.
details.example: Did you enjoy? / Did they go?

details.title: 'Be' Verb in Past Simple
details.content: In Past Simple, the verb 'be' changes to 'was' or 'were'. 'Was' is used with 'I', 'he', 'she', 'it'. 'Were' is used with 'you', 'we', 'they'.
details.example: I was angry because they were late.

details.title: Past Continuous - Example
details.content: Yesterday Karen and Jim played tennis. They began at 10 o'clock and finished at 11:30. So, at 10:30 they were playing tennis.
details.example: They were playing tennis.

details.title: Past Continuous Form
details.content: In Past Continuous, the structure is 'was/were + verb-ing'. Example: 'I was playing', 'They were doing'.
details.example: I was playing.

details.title: Usage of Past Continuous
details.content: Past Continuous is used to show that an action was in progress at a particular time in the past. The action started and was still ongoing.
details.example: I was doing.

details.title: Past Continuous for Actions at a Specific Time
details.content: For example, 'This time last year I was living in Brazil.' or 'What were you doing at 10 o'clock last night?'
details.example: I was living in Brazil.

details.title: Past Continuous vs. Past Simple
details.content: Past Continuous (I was doing) shows an action in progress, while Past Simple (did) shows a completed action. Example: 'Ann was watching television when the phone rang.'
details.example: Ann was watching television.

details.title: Past Continuous with Past Simple
details.content: Past Continuous is used to show an action in progress, and Past Simple is used to show a completed action. Example: 'Tom burnt his hand when he was cooking dinner.'
details.example: Tom burnt his hand.

details.title: Past Continuous with Past Simple - Sequence of Events
details.content: When one action happened after another, we use Past Simple for the second action. Example: 'I was walking along the road when I saw Dave.'
details.example: I saw Dave.

details.title: Examples of Past Continuous and Past Simple
details.content: Example 1: 'When Karen arrived, we were having dinner.' (The action was already in progress before Karen arrived.) Example 2: 'When Karen arrived, we had dinner.' (The action started after Karen arrived.)
details.example: When Karen arrived, we were having dinner.

details.title: Verbs Not Used in Continuous Tenses
details.content: Some verbs are not used in the continuous form. For example, 'know', 'want', and 'believe'.
details.example: We knew each other well.

details.title: Present Perfect Example
details.content: Tom is looking for his key. He can't find it. He has lost his key.
details.example: He has lost his key.

details.title: Present Perfect Form
details.content: In Present Perfect, the structure is 'have/has + past participle'. For example: 'I have lost', 'She has done'.
details.example: I have lost.

details.title: Present Perfect - Relation to Present
details.content: Present Perfect indicates a connection to the present. It is used to show the result of a past action. Example: 'I have lost it.' means that the key is still lost now.
details.example: I have lost it.

details.title: Present Perfect for Recent Events
details.content: Present Perfect is used to introduce new information or to talk about a recent event. Example: 'Ow! I've cut my finger.' or 'The road is closed. There's been an accident.'
details.example: I've cut my finger.

details.title: Present Perfect with Time Expressions
details.content: Present Perfect is often used with 'just', 'already', and 'yet'. These words give additional meaning to the time of the action.
details.example: I've just had lunch.

details.title: Using 'Just' in Present Perfect
details.content: 'Just' is used to describe something that happened very recently. Example: 'I've just had lunch.'
details.example: I've just had lunch.

details.title: Using 'Already' in Present Perfect
details.content: 'Already' is used to indicate that something has happened before the expected time. Example: 'I’ve already posted it.'
details.example: I've already posted it.

details.title: Using 'Yet' in Present Perfect
details.content: 'Yet' is used in negative sentences and questions, and it means 'still'. Example: 'Has it stopped raining yet?' or 'I haven't posted it yet.'
details.example: Has it stopped raining yet?

details.title: 'Gone to' vs 'Been to'
details.content: 'Gone to' is used when someone is still at the destination, while 'been to' indicates a visit that has already been completed. Example: 'Jim has gone to Spain.' vs 'Jane has been to Italy.'
details.example: Jim has gone to Spain.

details.title: 'Been to' vs 'Gone to' - More Examples
details.content: 'Gone to' means someone has left for a destination and might still be there. 'Been to' means the visit is complete. Example: 'Jim is on holiday. He has gone to Spain.' vs. 'Jane has been to Italy.'
details.example: Jane has been to Italy.

details.title: Present Perfect Example
details.content: Dave and Jane are talking about Jane's life experiences up to the present moment.
details.example: Dave: Have you travelled a lot, Jane? / Jane: Yes, I've been to lots of places.

details.title: Have You Ever / Been to
details.content: The Present Perfect tense is used to talk about experiences up to the present. Examples: 'Have you ever eaten caviar?' or 'I’ve been to China twice.'
details.example: Have you ever eaten caviar?

details.title: Examples of Present Perfect
details.content: Examples showing use of Present Perfect for events that occurred in the past but have relevance to the present. 'We’ve never had a car.' or 'She’s seen that film eight times.'
details.example: We've never had a car.

details.title: Past Experiences Related to Present
details.content: These examples indicate that the speaker is thinking about actions and experiences that occurred in the past but have some connection to the present. Example: 'What a boring film! It's the most boring film I’ve ever seen.'
details.example: It's the most boring film I’ve ever seen.

details.title: Have You Heard From Someone Recently?
details.content: Present Perfect can also be used to talk about actions or events that have happened recently. Examples: 'Have you heard from George recently?' or 'I’ve met a lot of people in the last few days.'
details.example: I’ve met a lot of people in the last few days.

details.title: Negative Sentences in Present Perfect
details.content: Present Perfect is used in negative sentences to show that something hasn't happened up to the present time. Example: 'We haven’t had any problems so far.' or 'I haven’t eaten anything since breakfast.'
details.example: We haven’t had any problems so far.

details.title: Long Time Without Seeing Someone
details.content: Present Perfect can be used to express a long period without seeing someone. Example: 'We haven’t seen each other for a long time.'
details.example: We haven’t seen each other for a long time.

details.title: Using Present Perfect for Ongoing Events
details.content: Present Perfect is used with time expressions like 'today', 'this morning', and 'this evening' to talk about actions that are still ongoing or unfinished. Example: 'I’ve drunk four cups of coffee today.'
details.example: I’ve drunk four cups of coffee today.

details.title: Asking About Holidays
details.content: Present Perfect can also be used for asking about past holidays or vacations. Example: 'Have you had a holiday this year?' or 'I haven’t seen Tom this morning. Have you?'
details.example: Have you had a holiday this year?

details.title: Working Hours
details.content: Present Perfect can be used to talk about work or activity during a specific period. Example: 'Ron hasn’t worked very hard this term.'
details.example: Ron hasn’t worked very hard this term.

details.title: Present Perfect Continuous Example
details.content: The Present Perfect Continuous is used to talk about actions that started in the past and are still continuing or have just finished.
details.example: It has been raining.

details.title: Is it raining? / Have you been running?
details.content: Examples using Present Perfect Continuous to ask about ongoing actions. Examples: 'Is it raining?' and 'Have you been running?'
details.example: Have you been running?

details.title: Describing Ongoing Actions
details.content: The Present Perfect Continuous tense is used to describe ongoing actions that started in the past but are still happening or have just been completed. Example: 'Paul is very tired. He's been working very hard.'
details.example: He's been working very hard.

details.title: Questioning Ongoing Actions
details.content: Present Perfect Continuous is often used to ask about activities that are still continuing. Example: 'Why are your clothes so dirty? What have you been doing?'
details.example: What have you been doing?

details.title: Ongoing Actions Over Time
details.content: Present Perfect Continuous can describe actions that started in the past and are continuing. Example: 'It has been raining for two hours.'
details.example: It has been raining for two hours.

details.title: How Long / For / Since
details.content: Present Perfect Continuous is often used with time expressions like 'How long', 'for', and 'since'. Example: 'How long have you been learning English?'
details.example: How long have you been learning English?

details.title: Recent Ongoing Actions
details.content: Present Perfect Continuous is used to describe actions that started recently and continue until now. Example: 'George hasn’t been feeling well recently.'
details.example: George hasn’t been feeling well recently.

details.title: Actions Continuing All Day
details.content: Present Perfect Continuous can describe activities that continue over a period of time. Example: 'Tim is still watching television. He's been watching television all day.'
details.example: He's been watching television all day.

details.title: Since and For with Ongoing Actions
details.content: Present Perfect Continuous often goes with 'since' and 'for' to describe the duration of actions. Example: 'She's been playing tennis since she was eight.'
details.example: She's been playing tennis since she was eight.

details.title: Comparing Present Continuous and Present Perfect Continuous
details.content: The Present Continuous describes actions happening right now, while the Present Perfect Continuous describes actions that started in the past and continue into the present. Example: 'I am working now' vs. 'I’ve been working hard, so I am tired.'
details.example: I’ve been working hard, so I am tired.

details.title: Present Perfect Continuous vs. Present Perfect
details.content: The difference between 'I have been doing' (Present Perfect Continuous) and 'I have done' (Present Perfect). The Present Perfect Continuous is used for actions that are ongoing or recently completed, while the Present Perfect focuses on the result or completion of an action.
details.example: She has been painting the ceiling.

details.title: Example: Ongoing vs Completed Actions
details.content: The Present Perfect Continuous is used for actions that are ongoing, while the Present Perfect focuses on the result of an action. Example: 'She has painted the ceiling' (completed action) vs 'She has been painting the ceiling' (ongoing action).
details.example: She has painted the ceiling.

details.title: Examples with 'Been Doing' and 'Done'
details.content: Examples comparing the two tenses: 'I've been repairing the car' (ongoing action) vs 'I've repaired it' (completed action).
details.example: I've been repairing the car.

details.title: Recent Actions and Results
details.content: Present Perfect Continuous is used to describe ongoing actions that are happening now or have just finished. The Present Perfect focuses on the completion of the action. Example: 'She's been smoking too much recently.' vs 'Somebody has smoked all my cigarettes.'
details.example: She's been smoking too much recently.

details.title: Question Forms in Present Perfect Continuous and Present Perfect
details.content: The Present Perfect Continuous can be used for asking about activities that are ongoing. Example: 'What have you been doing since we last met?' vs the Present Perfect asking about completed actions: 'What have you done to it?'
details.example: What have you been doing since we last met?

details.title: Using 'How Long' and 'How Many' with Continuous Actions
details.content: The Present Perfect Continuous is used to express actions that have been ongoing for a period of time. Example: 'How long have you been reading that book?' vs 'How many pages have you read?' (completed action).
details.example: How long have you been reading that book?

details.title: Actions Continuing All Day vs Completed Actions
details.content: The Present Perfect Continuous describes actions continuing over time, while the Present Perfect focuses on completed actions. Example: 'She's been writing letters all day' vs 'She has written ten letters today.'
details.example: She's been writing letters all day.

details.title: Comparing Frequency of Actions
details.content: The Present Perfect Continuous describes actions that have been occurring for a period of time, while the Present Perfect describes actions that have happened a certain number of times. Example: 'They've been playing tennis since 2 o'clock' vs 'They’ve played tennis three times this week.'
details.example: They’ve played tennis three times this week.

details.title: Verbs Not Used in Continuous Tenses
details.content: Certain verbs are not used in continuous tenses. These include verbs like 'know', 'like', and 'believe'. Example: 'I've known about it for a long time' is correct, but 'I’ve been knowing' is incorrect.
details.example: I've known about it for a long time.
